title: 104_s1857
content: The "Bipartisan Campaign Practices Commission Act of 1996" establishes the Bipartisan Commission on Campaign Practices with specific duties. The Bipartisan Campaign Practices Commission Act of 1996 establishes the Bipartisan Commission on Campaign Practices to study laws and regulations affecting Federal campaigns, make recommendations for change, and consider various factors such as campaign financing, candidate qualifications, trust in the political process, media access, and other relevant matters. The Bipartisan Campaign Practices Commission Act of 1996 establishes a Commission composed of 9 private sector members appointed by various officials. Within 7 days of appointments, members select a chairperson by majority vote, or risk discharge if no selection is made within 30 days. The Commission is composed of 9 private sector members appointed by officials. Members must select a chairperson within 7 days, or risk discharge if no selection is made within 30 days. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Each member is entitled to compensation based on the Executive Schedule. A quorum consists of 6 members, and decisions require the affirmative vote of 6 members. Meetings are called by the chairperson or at the request of 6 members. The chairperson of the Commission can appoint staff without following standard government hiring procedures. They can also hire temporary services as needed. Additionally, there are fast track procedures for recommendations within the Commission. SEC. 6. The Commission must submit a report to Congress within 30 days of the 105th Congress convening, detailing their study. Recommendations for changes in laws governing Federal campaigns may be included, with bills prepared for agreed-upon recommendations. These bills will receive expedited consideration by Congress. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting the report. $750,000 is authorized for this Act.
